content.description: A student conducts an experiment in which two solid rods, <math alttext="X" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>X</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="Y" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>Y</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> , are each held vertically with the bottom end just submerged in a bath of boiling water. The temperature of the room is <math alttext="21 degrees Celsius" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>21</mn><mo>°</mo><mtext>C</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> , and the rods are each <math alttext="80 centimeters" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>80</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.3em"></mspace><mtext>cm</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> long. After each rod has been in the water for the same amount of time, the student measures the temperature at <math alttext="20 centimeters" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>20</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.3em"></mspace><mtext>cm</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> intervals along each rod. The student’s data are shown below. Which of the following correctly describes an analysis of the data that can be used to compare the thermal conductivity of the rods?
content.question: Height Above Water <math alttext="in centimeters" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle choices.label: Compare the temperatures of the rods at <math alttext="0 centimeters" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mrow><mtext>0</mtext><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><mtext>cm</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> .
Compare the temperatures of the rods at each height.
Determine which rod has differences in temperatures between adjacent positions that are most similar for all pairs of positions.
The data cannot be used to compare the thermal conductivities because the top ends of the rods are not at room temperature.

content.answer: Compare the temperatures of the rods at each height.

skill.text: 3.B: Apply an appropriate law, definition, theoretical relationship, or model to make a claim.
